p.synopsis: “Fargo” opens with Jerry Lundegaard, played by William H. Macy, meeting with two crooks at a bar in Fargo, North Dakota. He plans to have the men kidnap his wife so he can split the ransom money with them from his wealthy father-in-law. The movie then continues with an amazing telling of how everything went wrong with Lundegaard’s plan. It stars the Minnesota police chief Marge Gunderson, played by Frances McDormand, who investigates what is going on when three people get killed as a result of the kidnapping going wrong.

body.p: The best part about the movie is the characters. All the actors did an amazing job in portraying their character. Each character is believable and life-like. William H. Macy especially did a great job with the character of Jerry Lundegaard. It is easy to see the distress he is under from his plan falling apart and how he still believes he can somehow pull it off even with absolutely nothing going his way. You see how much trouble he has dealing with all his problems, especially when he fails to call off the kidnapping after realizing he might not need it.

p.context: The character of Marge Gunderson, the police chief investigating the murders that followed the kidnapping, is another excellent character. As the star of the movie, she portrays the “Minnesota nice” stereotype, being friendly towards everyone she meets including those she interrogates and arrests.
p.opinions: It was great watching her intelligently piece together the case slowly up to the climax of the film.

body.p: The two men who kidnap Lundegaard’s wife were also great characters. Specifically Carl, played by Steve Buscemi. His character brings a good amount of humor into the film even with the dark plotline. His horrible attempt to deal with a state trooper, his conversations with his partner, and his ineptness work together to make him a great character. Everytime witnesses refer to him, they are only able to say that he was a “funny-looking guy”.

p.opinions: Even small characters in the movie where great. They really helped make the world of the film feel alive.
p.context: Marge’s husband had a painting contest he was in where he was trying to get one of his paintings on a stamp. He was also a sweet dude and it seemed like they had a great marriage. He wakes up early with her just to make her breakfast. Other characters with even fewer lines were amazing, and every character had accents and said lines such as “Yah, you betcha”.
p.opinions: The characters all worked together to make the movie come to life, like this story really could have happened in some small towns and suburbs in Minnesota.

p.aesthetics: The movie also looked fantastic. There were no confusing shots and you could see everything of importance in each one. Some wide shots were especially beautiful, such as when Marge finally confronts the kidnappers on a frozen lake. The aesthetics of it all were wonderful, and it was easy to tell how cold and desolate the setting is just by the colors on screen and all the snow.

body.p: The soundtrack also fit the movie perfectly. Each song went great with the scene it played in, although there were no standout memorable songs. Most just added to the scene to they were in to make it even better.

p.context: The Coen Brothers did a great job directing “Fargo”. They really captured the small town feel and told the story well with all their decisions.
p.opinions: I enjoyed the move a lot and I believe it is just as good as some of their other great films, such as “The Big Lebowski”.

conclusion.p: Overall, “Fargo” was a fantastic film. There is no question about how it was able to make $60 million at the box office on a budget of $7 million. It told a story realistically and did not try to answer every question, leaving some things open ended just like they are in real life. The characters were amazing and realistic and made the entire movie.

report.p: Great movie selection, I think Fargo is truly one of the best movies to have been released in the 90s. The piece written is a movie review, and a very effective one at that.The purpose of this piece is to share Dylan’s opinion on the movie, to a target audience residing predominantly on the internet. The structure of the piece is good, and all aspects (synopsis, conclusion, etc.) are sufficiently covered. I think the piece is very different form other reviews, in mostly due to its content. The review is focused very much on the characters in the movie, which is brilliantly represented. It is evident that the author has a very clear and deep understanding of how characterization works, and he effectively demonstrates this knowledge by reaping plot lines, quoting dialogues, and even going as far as examining their speech accents. I think these attributes truly appeal to the pathos, and the audience can actually understand and appreciate the characterization after reading this review. However, this review can still use some improvements. To start with, the author has focused almost solely on characterization. Albeit done effectively, the author may wish to explore the aspects of the movie. A good movie review covers all aspects of the movie. I believe the core aspects to review would be - quality of direction, screenplay, cinematography, acting, soundtrack, editing and plot. Whilst the author has touched on the soundtrack at the end of the review, the other key components are missing. I would suggest exploring the other key aspects of the review, and you wouldn’t have to get into so much in depth as you did with characterization. I believe that you can still keep characterization as the focus of your review, but perhaps very briefly share with the audience your opinion of the direction and screenplay. For example, in my piece I wrote: “Big, brash and bold. These words perfectly describe the aesthetics in this movie. Think of any lewd or vulgar action, and this movie probably has it. It's interesting to see that the direction isnt bad. Actually, the film is surprisingly well edited, shot and presented. Cinematography is top notch, and not a single shot feels out of place, or awkwardly edited.” It’s concise, and straight to the point. Overall, I am convinced that this piece is an effective representation of a movie review, and with the suggested edits it would be a great piece of work. .
